Coal combustion and the disposal of combustion wastes emit enormous quantities of nano-sized particles that pose significant health concerns on exposure, particularly in unindustrialized countries. Samples of fresh and weathered class F fly ash were analysed through various techniques including X-ray fluorescence (XRF), X-ray diffraction (XRD), focused ion beam scanning electron microscopy (FIB-SEM), field-emission gun scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM), high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) coupled with energy dispersive x-ray spectroscopy (EDS), and Raman Spectroscopy. The imaging techniques showed that the fresh andweathered coal fly ash nanoparticles (CFA-NPs) aremostly spherical shaped. The crystalline phases detected were quartz, mullite, ettringite, calcite, maghemite, hematite, gypsum, magnetite, clay residues, and sulphides. Themost abundant crystalline phaseswere quartzmixedwith Al-Fe-Si-K-Ti-O-amorphousphaseswhereasmullitewas detected in several amorphous phases of Al, Fe, Ca, Si, O, K,Mg,Mn, and P. sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
South Africa is a developing economy that relies heavily on electricity generated from coal-fired combustion processes due to its low-cost and availability (Nkomo, 2005). During the high-temperature combustion processes, mineral alteration generates a large number of ultrafine particles (Sambandam et al., 2015). The exposure of humans to such particulate matter is a major health concern in these countries (Sambandam et al., 2014).
In South Africa, indigenous power utility company (ESKOM) generates 37 Mt. of coal fly ash annually (ESKOM, 2009). Currently, about 1.85 Mt. is beneficially utilised, whereas about 35.15 Mt. is unused and dumped in landfills, ponds, or ash dams (Petrik et al., 2003; Akinyemi et al., 2011b). The sustainable management of the large volumes of coal fly ash produced from coal-fired power plants using low-grade coal to generate electricity is a major concern to the environment. Generally, coalmining, transportation, preparation, combustion, and coalfly ash storage activities result in several environmental impacts (LeónMejía et al., 2018). South African low-grade coal is pulverised and burned at a temperature of 1500 °C. Despite the high-temperature conditions, there is incomplete combustion of inorganic substances, which results in particulate coal fly ashes (CFA) (Burt et al., 2013; Silva et al., 2009; Silva and Kátia, 2011). These nano-sized particles infiltrate the tissue and organs of biological species resulting in swelling that alters the cellular redox balance through oxidation and ultimately cell demise (Breitner et al., 2011). Many epidemiological studies have linked exposure to ambient particulate matter (PM) to increased death and illnesses, which are ascribed to respiratory, cardiovascular or cardiopulmonary diseases, along with cancers of the liver and lungs (Zhou et al., 2005).
The emission of nanoparticles from coal combustion process poses danger to human health due to major elements such as Al, C, Ca, Fe, Mg, Na, S, Si and trace amounts of As, Ba, Cd, Cr, K, Mo, Mn, Nd, Pb, Rh, Se, Ti, V, and Zn (Okeson et al., 2003; Sambandam et al., 2014). Swaine and Goodarzi (1995) established four categories of trace elements in coal based on their environmental significance:
• Group I consist of hazardous elements such as As, Cd, Cr, Hg, and Se. • Group IIA elements include B, CI, F, Mn, Mo, Ni, and Pb, • Group IIB elements consist of Be, Cu, P, Th, U, V, and Zn, • Group III elements comprising Ba, Co, Sb, Sn, and Tl.
The composition of these elements in coal is determined by the ash yield, source areas, and geology (Gluskoter, 1975; Swaine, 1990).Moreover, coal and CFA particles typically consist of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs), organic, and carcinogenic nanoparticles (Burt et al., 2013; Liu et al., 2008; Sanchís et al., 2013; Sanchís et al., 2015). Activities such as residential heating, coal gasification, liquefying plants, carbon black, coal-tar pitch, asphalt production, coke production, motor vehicle exhaust and catalytic cracking towers in petroleum refineries, typically emit polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) (Saikia et al., 2018). The PAHs reportedly form diol-epoxides that covalently bind to DNA by metabolic activation (Jarvis et al., 2014; Singh et al., 2007). Furthermore, the semiquinone radicals generated undergo redox cycling, thereby forming reactive oxygen species (ROS) (Donaldson et al., 2005; Singh et al., 2007).
Nanoparticles transmit substantial quantities of air toxins, comprising the major portion of PAHs by weight (Eiguren-Fernandez et al., 2003; Li et al., 2003). PAHs typically exist in the gas-phase in the surrounding air and can act as an aerosol sorbet. Lastly, the potential of PAHs as mutagenic and cancer-causing compounds in animal systems is reported in the literature (Abdel-Shafy and Mansour, 2016).
Coal combustion and handling activities generate nano-sized particles as accidentalwaste products, which eventually capture other harmful elements in nature (Chen et al., 2005; Gieré et al., 2006; Hower et al., 2008). The fine grain size and high surface area enable coal fly ash particles to absorb hazardous elements, which are transmitted into byproducts during coal combustion (Güleç et al., 2001). Despite thehealth, safety, and environmental risks posed by the release of nanoparticles from dry-disposed coal fly ash dumps, there are limited studies in the literature on the subject.
Therefore, the main aim of this study is to identify, examine, and highlight the properties of coal-derived nanoparticles/nanomaterials in fresh and weathered coal fly ashes through advanced analysis and characterization techniques. These include; X-ray fluorescence (XRF), X-ray diffraction (XRD), field emission gun scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM), high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM), and Raman spectroscopy. The techniques will present insights into the mineralogy, surface composition, morphology, and the average bulk composition of the studied samples. Lastly, the study will discuss the health implications of ambient nanoparticles and the harmful elements released from both fresh and dry-disposed weathered coal fly ashes.

sections.heading: 2.1. Sampling technique
sections.text: A fresh coal fly ash (CFA) sample was collected from one of the ESKOM coal-fired power stations in South Africa. During coring of drilled borehole the auger came in contact with the water level at approximately 9.93 m depth. A composited unsaturated coal fly ash sample was collected from drilled borehole at depths above water level (≈9.93m)within the 20-year-old dry-disposed ash dump. The detailed sampling technique used in drilling core ash samples was reported in our previous study (Akinyemi et al., 2011a).

sections.heading: 2.2. Pore water chemistry
sections.text: Paste pH, EC, ORP and DOwere determined through weighing 100 g of air-dried fresh and weathered CFAs and 100 ml of de-ionised water inside a 250 ml glass beaker. After 5 min. continuous agitation using magnetic stirrer, slurry was obtained and allowed to stand for 10 min. The pH/pH + ORP/ISE, DO, EC, temperature probe (HANNA model: HI-7609829) were then inserted in the slurry and after swirling slightly the pH and EC, TDS, ORP and DO were measured until a constant value was obtained. After stirring and measurement of pH, EC, TDS, ORP and DO, samples were centrifuged for at 2500g for 20 min, and filtered through a 0.45 mm pore membrane filter. The procedure was duplicated and clear aqueous extract was left unacidified for anion analysis using 850 professional IC (Metrohmn, Switzerland).

sections.heading: 2.3. X-ray diffraction analysis
sections.text: The powder diffraction analysis was performed using a Philips PW1830 X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation. The ash samples were characterized to determine the minerals present using an ICDD Powder Diffraction reference file. Next, the quantitative analyses of the recognized mineral phases in the ash samples was performed using SIROQUANT™, which is a commercial interpretation software from CSIRO (Taylor, 1991) developed from the Rietveld (1969) method for x-ray diffraction analysis. The amorphous materials present in the ashes were characterized through the diffraction pattern of “tridymite” a poorly-crystalline mineral phase, according to the methods described in the literature (Ward and French, 2006).

sections.heading: 2.4. X-ray fluorescence & LA-ICPMS
sections.text: The bulk chemical composition of the major oxides (expressed as percentages) of the fresh and weathered CFAs was characterized using the Philips PW 2400 XRF spectrometer operating on the proprietary SuperQ software. Geochemical results obtained from XRF analysis were normalized to 100% volatile-free before plotting. Trace elements contents were determined by Laser Ablation-Induced Coupled Plasma Mass Spectroscopy (LA-ICP-MS). The procedure involved fusion of CFAs with a mixture of lithium tetraborate (Li2B4O7) and lithium metaborate (LiBO2) flux. The resultant digests were analysed by ICPMS, and the determined values were calculated as concentrations in the original CFAs samples. Accuracy, stated as a relative standard deviation percentage, is usually N5% for most elements analysed. Detailed sample preparation and analytical procedures for LA-ICP-MS techniques have been discussed by Akinyemi et al. (2012).

sections.heading: 2.5. Focused Ion Beam scanning electron microscopy
sections.text: The chemical analysis of the bulk particles was examined through a surface-sensitive technique. For this analysis, a Dual Focused Ion Beam (FIB) produced from a Helios 600 Nanolab™ FEI Dual Beam™ was employed. The FIB is equipped with a scanning electron microscope (SEM) which uses a high-resolution Field Emission Gun (FEG) with multiple electron detectors. These include a through-the-lens detector (TLD), an Everhart-Thornley detector (ETD), and a backscattered electron detector (BSED) for image acquisition. For each test, the precise area of interest was accurately selected and dissected by focusing a high resolution focused ion (Gaþ) beamwith a three-dimensional resolution of nearly 10 nm.

sections.heading: 2.6. Field-emission gun scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM) and highresolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM)
sections.text:
Field Emission Scanning Electron Microscope (FE-SEM) is a suitable tool for high-resolution surface imaging of nano-materials (Yao and Kimura, 2007) and has been previously employed to study coal and coal residues (Saikia et al., 2015), coal combustion fly ash particles (Silva et al., 2010), coal combustion products derived from high-Ge coals (Dai et al., 2014), and coal combustion residues (Ribeiro et al., 2013a). HR-TEM is the dominant analytical technique employed in the study of nanoparticles, it's structure, chemistry, dimensions, and morphology of atmospheric particles (Silva et al., 2010). HR-TEM also presents the full shape of the nanostructure of individual particles in coal and CFAs (Saikia et al., 2018). HR-TEM has been used to study Fenanominerals within coal fly ash (Silva et al., 2009). In this study, the morphology, crystal structure, surface topography, and chemical analysis of ultrafine particles were examined using a Dual Beam Focused Ion Beam (FIB) generated by FEI DualBeam™ Helios 600 Nanolab™. The FIB-SEM is equipped with the following principal components; a highresolution Field Emission Gun (FEG) for SEM, multiple electron detectors for image acquisition such as through-the-lens detector (TLD), an
Everhart-Thornley detector (ETD), and a backscattered electron detector (BSED) for compositional information. Other components include; a high resolution focused ion (Gaþ) beam to accurately select and slice an image in a specific region of interest at a spatial resolution of about 10 nm. In addition to FIB-SEM, an EnergyDispersive X-Ray Spectroscopy (EDS) was employed in this study. Experimental procedures for electron microprobe were performed by field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM), high-resolution transmission electron microscope (HR-TEM) with selected area electron diffraction (SAED) and/or convergent beam electron diffraction (CBED). Other techniques include scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM), and energydispersive X-ray spectrometer (EDS) analyses which are discussed in previous studies (Oliveira et al., 2018; Saikia et al., 2018; Silva et al., 2009).

sections.heading: 2.7. Raman spectroscopy
sections.text: The Raman spectroscopy analysis was performed using a Lab-Ram microscope (HORIBA John Yvon Ltd., USA). The device was fitted with a HeNe laser (l) and a data recorder. Next, the data analysis was performed on the LabSpec trademarked software by HORIBA Jobin Yvon. Prior to the test, the samples were illuminated with 542-nm wavelength for excitation operated on a Dell OptiPlex personal computer (PC).

sections.heading: 3.1. Mineralogical composition and morphology
sections.text:
The results of the quantitative mineralogical analyses of the fresh and weathered dry-disposed coal fly ash samples are shown in Fig. 1. The dominant phases in both samples are amorphous (trimydite) followed by mullite and quartz. However, calcite, ettringite, and maghemite occurred in minor quantities.
Fig. 2 depicts the microstructure and morphology of the studied samples. The fresh and weathered coal fly ash nanoparticles (CFANPs) are mainly spherical in shape, as observed in Fig. 2b & c. The SEM images confirmed the presence of quartz and amorphous mineral phases in the weathered CFA, as observed in Fig. 2b. However, the fresh CFA exhibited a smooth appearance due to aluminosilicate glass, as observed in Fig. 2c. The muddy appearance of weathered CFA is attributed to decomposition and precipitation of amorphous aluminosilicate minerals, as observed in Fig. 2a. The spherical shape is typically suggestive of particulates moulded during high-temperature combustion processes such as coagulation, condensation, and nucleation of evaporatedmaterials (Heasman andWatt, 1989). The particles typically generated during high-temperature combustion are in the range from nanoscale to microscale (0.001–10 μm) (Kimbrough, 1998). The glassy particles in coal fly ash typically range from nano-sized, 10 nm to 100 nm, and consist largely of Fe‑aluminum silicate glass with accessory hematite and Fe-sulphate (Silva et al., 2009).

sections.heading: 3.2. Geochemical analysis
sections.text:
Table 1 depicts the physicochemical parameters of the fresh and weathered CFAs examined in this study. The average pH, electrical
conductivities (EC), and total dissolved solids (TDS) of fresh CFA are relatively higher than weathered CFA, which can be ascribed to the flushing of basic soluble oxides. The average values of oxidation-reduction potential (ORP) and dissolved oxygen (DO) are considerably higher in the WCFA compared to FCFA, signifying continuous chemical reactions between the CFAs and ingressed O2 and percolating rainwater (Akinyemi et al., 2011b).
The contents of the anion species in the studied sample are shown in Table 1. The concentrations of NO3−N, Cl−, and SO42−, but not PO43−, are relatively depleted in weathered coal fly ash (WCFA) compared to fresh coal fly ash (FCFA). This obvious depletion trend is an indication of flushing/leaching of basic soluble oxides in the weathered coal fly ash, as described in the literature (Akinyemi et al., 2011b; Gitari et al., 2009). The results of X-ray fluorescence analysis of the pulverised coal and fresh CFA from same power station were reported in our previous study (Akinyemi et al., 2011b; Akinyemi et al., 2012). The most abundant major oxide constituents in both pulverised coal and fresh CFA samples are Si followed by Al, Fe, and Ca. Conversely, the least abundant constituents are Ti, Mg, Na, K, P, Cr and Mn.
The XRF data of weathered CFA was normalized with that of the fresh CFA to give ratios that indicate the relative enrichment or depletion of various species with respect to the fresh CFA. The major oxide
constituents such as Fe, Ca, Mg, Mn, Ti, P, Na, and K were enriched in fresh coal fly ash. Trace elements such as U, Cr, Th, V, Ni, Cu, Zn, Rb, Sr, Mo, Hf, Ta, Pb, Cr, Zr, Nb, and Sn were relatively enriched in the coal fly ash. In contrast, W, As, Cs, and Ba are significantly enriched in the pulverised coal samples used in the combustion process. The rare earth element (REE) constituents such as La, Ce, Pr, Nd, Sm, Eu, and Gd are slightly enriched in the coal fly ash. However, Lu, Y, Dy, Tb, Yb, Tm, Er, and Ho are noticeably enriched in the fresh coal fly ash. The
obvious relative enrichment and depletion of elements are attributed to conditions of the combustion process in this coal-fired power station.

sections.heading: 3.3. Field-emission gun scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM)
sections.text:
The examined CFA samples contained crystalline particles with agglomerated amorphous phases (there are no 100% crystalline particles). The most abundant minerals were in the order: quartz and mullite.

However, other minerals such as ettringite, maghemite, hematite, gypsum, calcite were detected lower concentrations than quartz and mullite. A total of twenty-three examined particles contained quartz mixed with Al-Fe-Si-K-Ti-O-amorphous phases. In contrast, mullite was the most abundant mineral found in seventy-seven analysed particles along with some associated amorphous phases of Fe, Al, Si, O, K, Mg, Mn, P, and Ca (Fig. 3a&b). One hundred and nine particles examined contained potentially hazardous elements (PHEs) such as Be, As, Co, Cr, Cd, Cu, Hg, Mn, Ni, Sb, Se, Sr, V, U, Th, and Ti. During combustion, the temperature, pressure, and amount of oxygen vary largely due to the heterogeneity of feedstock coals. Accordingly, the shape and harmfulness of fly ash particles also depend on the coal preparation method, combustion conditions, boiler type and construction, in addition to the type and efficiency of air pollution control devices (Juda-Rezler and Kowalczyk, 2013). The quantitative analyses by ESD are approximate because elements of lower atomic weights such as H, F, O, and C,
amongmany others, are poor electron emitters (Silva et al., 2010). Consequently, the quantification is not reliable; hence EDS graphs were preferably used in this study (Fig. 3a&b).
The EDS analysis detected zircons along with Sr-U-bearing Al-Si amorphous phases. The resulting trend indicates that zircon is originally present in the feedstock coal at the power plant.
Fig. 4 shows a transmission electron microscopy (TEM) bright-field image of hematite with EDS analysis, which indicates the presence of trivalent iron oxide. The fourty-seven particles analysed contained As, Hg, Ni, Mo, and Sb and particles of hematite or maghemite. However, some particles may or not include S-bearing Fe-amorphous phases (Fig. 4), which contains potentially hazardous elements (PHEs). Therefore, this indicates that the Fe particles have the ability to adsorb relatively volatile elements, which can be released into the atmosphere.

The tendency of jarosite to scavenge metals or oxyanions in drainage acid mine sites has been widely reported for different elements (Silva et al., 2011a; Silva et al., 2011b; Silva et al., 2011d). sections.heading: 3.4. High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM)
sections.text:
Fifty-three particles were selected and prepared by FIB-SEM for analysis by HR-TEM. The detailed procedure is described in section 2.4 (Oliveira et al., 2018). Paths containing Ti, unfortunately, could not be well photographed because the particles are below 200 nm (Fig. 5).
Next, the particles were prepared by FIB-SEM and evaluated by HRTEM/SAED/FFT/EDS.
Fig. 6a&c show the carbon species detected as 5–50-nm carbon nanoballs. These are comparable to black carbon or smut, which comprise centrally arranged layers of graphite (Fig. 6b) (Silva et al., 2010). The aggregates arranged in fractal order were found to vary in size while exhibiting a micro texture comprising of uneven, centrallyarranged layers of graphite (Fig. 6b). Graphite is essentially a carbonbased crystal structure that accounts for the dark and wet characteristics of powdered fly ash. In addition, it is the foremost constituent of smoke arising from the burning of carbon-based organic fuels under oxygen-deficient conditions (Chen et al., 2006). Fig. 6 shows massive fullerenes formed from the high-temperature treatment of metalcatalysed soot. This alters the characteristic amorphous aggregates of sooty carbon into regularly shaped fullerenes (i.e. nano‑carbon ball) that are usually associated with metals, including As and Hg (Cobo et al., 2009; Silva et al., 2010). sections.heading: 3.5. Raman spectroscopy
sections.text:
The results revealed crystalline phases that was undetectable during XRD analysis (Section 2.1). However, Raman spectroscopy detected quartz, mullite, ettringite, calcite, and maghemite, along with hematite, gypsum, and magnetite. In addition, clay residues (kaolinite, illite, and smectite) and sulphides (pyrite, marcasite, chalcopyrite, and sphalerite) that were not degraded in the high temperature boiler were also detected. The presence of pyrite is typically due its presence in clays, which generate spheres when dehydrated (at high temperatures) resulting in encapsulation and preservation of pyrite (Quispe et al., 2012). Iron oxides (mainly hematite and magnetite) (Fig. 7b) are the main coal fly ash products of pyrite oxidation, although occasionally this occurs through the
intermediate formation of pyrrhotite (Silva et al., 2011c). According to Silva et al. (2009) and Oliveira et al. (2012), this occurs when the phases are “protected” within the amorphous structure. Subsequently, the elements are released over time into the environment in the form of potentially hazardous elements (PHEs) which pose health risks to humans.
The influence of hazardous elements in CFAs and weathered CFAS is attributed to the association of these elements with amorphous phases, clays, and oxides (Figs. 3, 4, 7 and 8). This observation agrees with the previous study on anthracite fly ash (Ribeiro et al., 2013b).
The geochemical fractionation studies reported in our previous study (Nyale et al., 2014), indicated fairly high mobility for As, Zn, Pb, Ni, Mo, Cr, and Cu in the amorphous phase of fresh and weathered CFAs. For example, the present study indicates significant leaching of As, Se, Mo, Cr, and Hg, probably because it is in amorphous nano particulate form, which makes the elements less stable in the environment, thereby releasing the PHEs.
Lately, the interest in the health risks associated with ultrafine particles such as derived fly ash from combustion has soared. According to Silva et al. (2009), the growing interest will advance the understanding of the toxicological mechanisms of coal fly ash and similar combustion-generated particles on human health
and the environment. However, the optimal approach to classify and appraise the risks of nano compounds to human health and safety and to the environment remains a topic of debate among scientists (Cutruneo et al., 2014; Oliveira et al., 2018; Ribeiro et al., 2013a).

sections.heading: 3.6. Toxicity and cytotoxicity of nanoparticles
sections.text:
South Africa fly ashes (class F) originated from sub-bituminous coal that generally produces alkaline ash that is relatively low in sulphur (Fresh CFA≈ 012wt% and weathered CFA≈ 0.29 wt%) and rich in calcium (Fresh CFA ≈ 6.38 wt% and weathered CFA ≈ 4.66 wt%) contents (Akinyemi et al., 2011b; Akinyemi et al., 2012). Elements such as As, B, Mo, S, and Se are typically enriched in fly ash particles (Aitken and Bell, 1985; Page et al., 1979). Previous studies also have shown that As, Cd, Cu, Mo, Pb, S, Se, Tl, and Zn concentrations generally increase with decreasing particle size due to volatilization during the combustion process and condensation in the ash-collection
system (Davison et al., 1974; Natusch et al., 1975). These hazardous elements are likely to have been deposited on the surface layer of fly ash particles rather than within the glassy particles (Steenari et al., 1999).
CFAs are ultra-fine and nanometric materials (b100 nm). Electrostatic precipitators and other less efficient technologies only have efficiency up to 1um particles. Of course, many nanoparticles will be emitted from the coal power plants chimney. Fly ash particles are recycled as construction materials for instance some coal power plants sell the CFAs for cement industries. The nanoparticles and highlymobile potential hazardous (PHEs) elements are emitted during transportation, uncontrolled dumping and application of CFAs in the cement industry
(Silva et al., 2009; Quispe et al., 2012; Silva et al., 2012a; Silva et al., 2012b; Kronbauer et al., 2013).
The ultrafine and nano compounds (minerals and amorphous phases) detected in this study encapsulate hazardous elements in the nanometer size range (Figs. 3, 4, 7 & 8). The diameter (≈500 nm) of the nano-spheres present severe concerns associatedwith environmental impact and human health through inhalation (Fig. 2b&c). The spheres below 1 μm are highly worrisome for human health, as they can reach the lungs and even the bloodstream (Ribeiro et al., 2013b; Silva et al., 2012a, 2012b). Titanium dioxide (TiO2) (anatase and rutile) nanoparticles reportedly trigger adverse pulmonary responses in vulnerable animals (Iavicoli et al., 2012). The anatase TiO2 nanoparticles producemore free radicals than rutile form and, therefore, higher toxicity than the rutile TiO2 nanoparticle. The anatase TiO2 nanoparticles are one of the main sources of inflammation and cytotoxicity (Yang et al., 2017).
Similarly, iron oxide (hematite and magnetite) nanoparticles detected in this study (Fig. 8), contain hazardous elements (such as As, Hg, V, and Mo) that could have significant health effects. Related in vivo studies have indicated that pulmonary contact with iron oxide nanoparticles (IONPs) can trigger genotoxicity and inflammation along with effects such as pulmonary and extra-pulmonary fibrosis (Kornberg et al., 2017). Magnetite nanoparticles are potentially toxic to the brain due to their susceptibility to react with external magnetic fields. These have also been implicated in the production of damaging reactive oxygen species (ROS) (Maher et al., 2016). In addition, hematite nanoparticles enhanced the growth of soil bacteria (Rajendran et al., 2017). Typical jarosite was detected around Fe-S amorphous particles containing hazardous elements such as As, Se, and Hg (Fig. 4b). The cubic-shaped jarosite appears to be a pseudomorph after pyrite. Dehydration of jarosite can lead to the formation of less-hydrous Fe sulfates and hematite (Silva and Oliveira, 2015).

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text: Coal combustion and dry-disposal of coal fly ash can discharge several pollutants, including nanoparticles or nanomaterials and potential hazardous elements (such as Be, As, Co, Cr, Cd, Cu, Hg, Mn, Ni, Sb, Se, Sr, V, U, Th, and Ti) into the environment. The cutting-edge analytical techniques including FE-SEM, HR-TEM, FIB-SEM, and Raman spectroscopy are necessary to determine the chemical composition at the nanoscale in order to decrease the health hazards due to potential exposure. The chemistry of nanoparticle/nano minerals seeks to improve knowledge on its adverse effects on human health and the environment. The people in the neighbourhood of the dry-disposed ash dumpare exposed towind-blownweathered coalfly ashes,which contain nanoparticles as well as potentially hazardous elements (PHEs). This study creates awareness for policymakers on the need to revisit coal combustion and waste handling activities with a view to minimising potential health hazards.
